description:
Plasmodium berghei ANKA is a rodent malaria parasite that is widely used as an experimental model for studying the biology and pathogenesis of malaria. It is a protozoan parasite belonging to the genus Plasmodium, which is the causative agent of malaria in various vertebrate hosts, including humans.

The Plasmodium berghei ANKA strain is a cloned line of the original P. berghei parasite, which was isolated from the thicket rat (Grammomys surdaster) in the former Democratic Republic of the Congo (then known as the Belgian Congo). This strain is known for its ability to cause a severe and often lethal form of experimental malaria in laboratory mice, particularly the C57BL/6 strain.

The life cycle of P. berghei ANKA is similar to that of other Plasmodium species, involving both sexual and asexual stages. The parasite is transmitted by the bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes, which introduce the sporozoite stage into the host's bloodstream. The sporozoites then travel to the liver, where they multiply and develop into merozoites, which are released into the bloodstream to infect red blood cells.

Inside the red blood cells, the parasites undergo further multiplication and development, eventually leading to the production of gametocytes, which can be taken up by mosquitoes during a blood meal, completing the life cycle.

The P. berghei ANKA strain is particularly useful for studying the pathogenesis of cerebral malaria, a severe complication of malaria infection that can lead to neurological symptoms and potentially fatal outcomes. The strain has been extensively used in animal models to investigate the underlying mechanisms of disease progression, the host immune response, and the development of potential therapeutic interventions.
